However, once runner $B$ reaches full speed, every additional second provides him more ground covered since it matches what runner $A$ covers fully ($a$). Therefore AC& =>BA-AB+\&\lt;\!AM

direct_answer.text: We know that $\triangle POE$, $\triangle BEO$, and $\triangle AOB$ are similar. Moreover, since $P$ lies on line $BE$ extended past both ends of it, $PE = EB$. Thus, $\triangle PEB$ is equilateral. Consequently, each interior angle equals $60^\circ$. Denoting the measure of angle $PBO$ as $a$ radians (we assume $a > 0$), notice that we get the inequality $2\pi = 60a + 2\cdot arctan \frac{|BA|}{r} + 2\cdot arctan \frac{|BC|}{r}$, whence solving leads us to conclude that $a$ satisfies $[-\tfrac{1}{\pi}, -\tfrac{1}{\pi}]$. Note furthermore that equality holds precisely when lines passing through centers $O$ coincide exactly. Henceforth, considering those conditions arise one obtains either zero ($+\infty$) or negative infinity (-$\infty$). However, note also how strictly speaking applying limits does indeed provide some insight into what happens otherwise but lacks clarity about why things work out in particular ways especially near boundaries [see other answers]. ost_step.1: Let the speed of runner $A$ be $v$, so the speed of runner $B$ is $3v$.
ost_step.2: Without loss of generality, assume runner $A$ starts first and moves clockwise around the circular path centered at $O$. After time $t$, both runners return to $O$. Thus, during any period of time less than one hour ($60$ minutes or some multiple thereof), it makes no difference whether you measure distances along the circumference of the unit circle having diameter $[AP]$ (the orange arc segment above) versus directly northward along line segments through $O$ ([AB](https://latex.codecogs.com/png.image?\dpi{110}&space;\bg_white&space;\huge&space;\small%5Cincludegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{circularunitcircle})) .   Step 3: Because each leg of runner $B$’s journey takes him exactly one third as long as those legs taken by runner $A$, angles drawn opposite his arcs trace out precisely half of what traces out over [AB], namely angle $\theta$. Each cycle therefore yields twice as much change in orientation relative to straight up compared with how often [AB] gets rotated itself. Specifically , the amount gained via direct observation equals ${2}\times$$\left|\
ost_step.3: Finally, observe that since runner $A$ travels counterclockwise while observers remain stationary, whereas runner $B$ completes about double trips every round he finishes, thus taking them farther away faster when measuring displacements due east ($\pm y$), west ($\mp y$) directions rather than strictly south ($\mp x$). Hence our earlier statement implies $$\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{Y}{\Delta X_{\text{max}}}\right)\leq\frac{\Omega}{k}, $$so substituting appropriately produces $\displaystyle {\Theta<\arctan(6)=\dfrac{1}{3}\arctan\left(\dfrac{6^{\large 2}+1^{\large 2}}{6\cdot1}\right)}\approx18^\circ.$

subanswer.text: We know that $Bob$ moves faster, being thrice as quick as $Alice$. Thus when $Alice$ takes steps measuring one unit each second along her path, $Bob$ makes three equal strides right beside her within those very few fractions of a moment before he catches up to her. Now imagine both $Charles$and his friend standing together exactly opposite from him - side facing side - watching them walk over what amounts to not quite four whole feet long according to our diagram.
